prs.l: chiefly in Britain, eastern New England, northeastern Virginia, and sometimes elsewhere in cultivated speech

dt: {bc}the usually large, rounded, edible, pulpy berry of an herb (genus {it}Solanum{/it}) of the {d_link|nightshade|nightshade} family native to South America that is typically red but may be yellow, orange, green, or purplish in color and is eaten raw or cooked as a vegetable
{bc}any of various varieties of a tender perennial ({it}Solanum lycopersicum{/it} synonym {it}Lycopersicon esculentum{/it}) widely cultivated as an annual

pt: The original pronunciation of this Spanish loanword was with stressed \ä\, as was also the case for {it}potato{/it}. The older \ä\ pronunciation of {it}potato{/it} is found in Robert Burns' poem {ldquo}Holy Willie's Prayer{rdquo} and persists in some Scottish dialects. Perhaps because {it}potato{/it} has been part of English longer than {it}tomato{/it}, its pronunciation has been anglicized in most dialects, with the stressed \ä\ vowel becoming \ā\, like the {it}a{/it} in {it}Plato{/it} (from Greek) and {it}dado{/it} (from Italian). The pronunciation of {it}tomato{/it} began the same journey of anglicization but was halted halfway between, so that British and some Eastern American dialects have the older \ä\ while the others have the newer \ā\. {it}Tomato{/it}, being the name of a New World plant, might have entered the English language first in the Americas, where it would have had more time to undergo anglicization in American mouths. The various pronunciations of {it}tomato{/it} are all acceptable in standard English.

et: alteration of earlier {it}tomate{/it}, from Spanish, from Nahuatl {it}tomatl{/it}
shortdef: the usually large, rounded, edible, pulpy berry of an herb (genus Solanum) of the nightshade family native to South America that is typically red but may be yellow, orange, green, or purplish in color and is eaten raw or cooked as a vegetable
a plant that produces tomatoes; especially : any of various varieties of a tender perennial (Solanum lycopersicum synonym Lycopersicon esculentum) widely cultivated as an annual

dt: {bc}a North American hawk moth ({it}Manduca quinquemaculata{/it}) whose green larva is a hornworm feeding on leaves of plants of the nightshade family and especially tobacco and tomato

shortdef: a North American hawk moth (Manduca quinquemaculata) whose green larva is a hornworm feeding on leaves of plants of the nightshade family and especially tobacco and tomato
a thick sauce made with tomatoes

dt: {bc}a very large globe-shaped red tomato with dense flesh

shortdef: a very large globe-shaped red tomato with dense flesh

dt: {bc}a small globose red or orange tomato borne in long dense clusters
{bc}a tropical American plant ({it}Lycopersicon esculentum cerasiforme{/it}) bearing cherry tomatoes

shortdef: a small globose red or orange tomato borne in long dense clusters; also : a tropical American plant (Lycopersicon esculentum cerasiforme) bearing cherry tomatoes

dt: {bc}a stout hairy annual herb ({it}Physalis pruinosa{/it}) of eastern North America with sweet globular yellow fruits

shortdef: ground-cherry; especially : a stout hairy annual herb (Physalis pruinosa) of eastern North America with sweet globular yellow fruits
